name: Npm
help: npm is the package manager for the Node JavaScript platform. It puts modules in place so that node can find them, and manages dependency conflicts intelligently.<para/>It is extremely configurable to support a wide variety of use cases. Most commonly, it is used to publish, discover, install, and develop node programs.

tasks.help:
Install a project with a clean slate. This command is similar to npm install, except it's meant to be used in automated environments such as test platforms, continuous integration, and deployment or any situation where you want to make sure you're doing a clean install of your dependencies. It can be significantly faster than a regular npm install by skipping certain user-oriented features. It is also more strict than a regular install, which can help catch errors or inconsistencies caused by the incrementally-installed local environments of most npm users.

In short, the main differences between using npm install and npm ci are:

  • The project must have an existing package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json.
  • If dependencies in the package lock do not match those in package.json, npm ci will exit with an error, instead of updating the package lock.
  • npm ci can only install entire projects at a time: individual dependencies cannot be added with this command.
  • If a node_modules is already present, it will be automatically removed before npm ci begins its install.
  • It will never write to package.json or any of the package-locks: installs are essentially frozen.

Installs a package, and any packages that it depends on. If the package has a package-lock or shrinkwrap file, the installation of dependencies will be driven by that, with an npm-shrinkwrap.json taking precedence if both files exist. See package-lock.json and npm-shrinkwrap.A package is:
  • a) A folder containing a program described by a package.json file
  • b) A gzipped tarball containing (b)
  • c) A url that resolves to (b)
  • d) a <name>@<version> that is published on the registry (see npm-registry) with (c)
  • e) a <name>@<tag> (see npm-dist-tag) that points to (d)
  • f) a <name> that has a "latest" tag satisfying (e)
  • g) a <git remote url> that resolves to (a)

properties.name: Packages
properties.help: List of packages to be installed.

properties.name: Production
properties.help: Causes npm to not install modules listed in devDependencies.

properties.name: Force
properties.help: Forces npm to fetch remote resources even if a local copy exists on disk.

properties.name: Global
properties.help: Causes npm to install the package globally rather than locally. See npm-folders.

properties.name: GlobalStyle
properties.help: Causes npm to install the package into your local <c>node_modules</c> folder with the same layout it uses with the global <c>node_modules</c> folder. Only your direct dependencies will show in <c>node_modules</c> and everything they depend on will be flattened in their <c>node_modules</c> folders. This obviously will eliminate some deduping.

properties.name: IgnoreScripts
properties.help: Causes npm to not execute any scripts defined in the package.json. See npm-scripts.

properties.name: LegacyBundling
properties.help: Causes npm to install the package such that versions of npm prior to 1.4, such as the one included with node 0.8, can install the package. This eliminates all automatic deduping.

properties.name: Link
properties.help: Cause npm to link global installs into the local space in some cases.

properties.name: NoBinLinks
properties.help: Prevents npm from creating symlinks for any binaries the package might contain.

properties.name: NoOptional
properties.help: Prevents optional dependencies from being installed.

properties.name: NoShrinkWrap
properties.help: Ignores an available shrinkwrap file and use the package.json instead.

properties.name: NodeDir
properties.help: Allows npm to find the node source code so that npm can compile native modules.

properties.name: Only
properties.help: Causes either only <c>devDependencies</c> or only non-<c>devDependencies</c> to be installed regardless of the <c>NODE_ENV</c>.

tasks.help: Runs an arbitrary command from a package's <c>"scripts"</c> object. If no <c>"command"</c> is provided, it will list the available scripts. <c>run[-script]</c> is used by the test, start, restart, and stop commands, but can be called directly, as well. When the scripts in the package are printed out, they're separated into lifecycle (test, start, restart) and directly-run scripts."
